chargeHist.descr: Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent

result.execSummary:
The defendant Maggie Sue Nemec was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(2).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: Payment of outstanding financial obligations. Failure to pay as required will result in a civil judgment being entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Per Wis Stat- Funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Per Wis Stat- Funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

Pay as required by Clerk of Courts. Failure to pay as required will result in a civil judgment being entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Per Wis Stat- Funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.
Programming as deemed appropriate by DOC.
Restitution to remain open 30 days. - No restitution ordered after the 30 day wait.

records.addlTxt:
10:59 AM Defendant Maggie Sue Nemec in court, in custody.  Attorney Lance Morgan Nelsen in court for Maggie Sue Nemec.  Attorney Peter James Marvin Kruger in court for State of Wisconsin. State recites agreement that defendant to plead to sole count. For that count, 7 years prison fashioned as 4 years initial confinement and 3 years extended supervision imposed and stayed for 4 years probation. Conditions of probation include pay a fine of $50 plus costs, serve 27 days jail with credit for 27 days, continuation of no contact with Victim #1, comply with all programming as deemed necessary by the Dept of Corrections and restitution to remain open for 30 days. Defendant pleads no contest. Attorney Nelsen stipulates to a factual basis. Court accepts the Defendant's plea and finds that the Defendant's plea has been freely, voluntarily and intelligently made. The Defendant understands all the rights she is waiving by her plea. The Defendant is found guilty and Judgment of Conviction is entered.

Court imposes 7 years prison fashioned as 4 years initial confinement and 3 years extended supervision imposed and stayed for 4 years probation. Conditions of probation include pay a fine of $50 plus costs, serve 27 days jail with credit for 27 days, continuation of no contact with Victim #1, comply with all programming as deemed necessary by the Dept of Corrections and restitution to remain open for 30 days. Conditions of extended supervision if revoked, payment of outstanding financial obligations to include restitution.
Bail/bond hearing on August 8, 2022 at 10:30 am.
Defendant's Notice of Motion and Motion for Reduction of Bail
State's Demand for Discovery and Inspection
